stories.title: GDevelop – no-code approach to building games

stories.text:
I haven't handwritten since 1997 and I now need to re-study mathematics from the very beginning for which I'm planning to use the material shared by OpenStax (https://openstax.org/subjects/math) with the GeoGebra tools (https://www.geogebra.org/).
Is there any software application (preferably running under GNU/Linux, or Web-based) which I could use to work through the problems mentioned in the OpenStax curriculum?
Essentially, a replacement for handwriting using pen/pencil and paper!
stories.title: Can't handwrite, any software alternative for math?

stories.text:
Hello, I'm a CS student and have been extremely interested in so-called "transformative tools for thought" [1].

Some examples I'm currently thinking about are Roam, Notion, Muse, and Obsidian.

I'm especially interested in more touch/visual based tools for thought, rather than text-based tools.

[1]: https://numinous.productions/ttft/
stories.title: Ask HN: What are the most promising transformative tools for thought today?
Example – Single-board computers for control robotics with the power of thought
Show HN: A free tool to batch download TikTok videos without watermark
Seekwatcher – visualize IO patterns and performance on Linux
A Badass Way to Connect Programs Together (2016)
Zydis – Fast and lightweight x86/x86-64 disassembler and code generation library
